Award.AwardTitle: ENGAGING SBE: Workshop for Engaging Social, Behavioral, and Economic Scientists through Social and Policy Entrepreneurship

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration: Accessible, actionable, and relevant scientific knowledge holds promise for providing significant societal benefits. However, identifying the mechanisms by which such knowledge makes it way into the appropriate social entrepreneurship and public policy streams remains a challenge. This workshop is to discuss and develop a systematic approach for collecting, aggregating, and examining information and experiences across sectors to develop an understanding of the dynamics of successful social partnerships and devise strategies for effectively channeling scientific knowledge into social policy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This report presents findings from a National Science Foundation funded workshop, “Catalyzing Discovery for Social Impact: Exploring the Power of the Research-Academic-Policy Nexus to Stimulate Policy Innovation.”  This two-day event, held September 4-6, 2013, brought together national policymakers, policy school deans and faculty, research center and think tank leadership, and practitioners, to provide new understandings of how innovative social science research is successfully translated to the policy sector through partnerships between academics, researchers, and policymakers. The workshop was designed to accomplish the following: 

  • A systematic exploration of factors undergirding successful collaborative relationships between academics and policymakers,
  • Examination of key processes and mechanisms which help drive the movement of innovative social science research into the policymaking sphere,
  • Identification of characteristics, skills, and motivations of those who form and nurture relationships between academia and the policy community, and 
  • Identification of key characteristics, incentives, cultures, and operations of the academic and policy communities that facilitate the movement of innovative research products to public stakeholders. 

To drive initial discussions at the workshop, key questions were designed to reveal core features of each element:

  • Environment: What environmental characteristics exist within each sector that create fertile ground for translating research into practical policy solutions? 
  • Leadership: What individual or collective leadership qualities are present within those who seek to enable the translation of social science research into usable policy solutions?  
  • Process: What dynamics emerge to support effective interactions between the scientific and policymaking communities and how are these operationalized?

Workshop Day 1 Findings

Four individuals from the larger sample of possible workshop participants prepared written descriptions of their organizations and experiences, which served as illustrative cases to start the workshop discussions.  The written cases shared similar features:

1)    Institutions and leaders were open to taking a risk and supported the “catalysts” in explicit ways,

2)    Participants in the collaboration were committed to the process,

3)    Catalytic qualities present in the policy entrepreneur/boundary spanner,

4)    Built off of pre-existing networks, initiatives, and formal structures; focused on long-term relationship building,

5)    Aligned professional interests of partners and created shared value in the initiative’s goals, and

6)    New incentives and methodologies for participation developed

In addition, four core insights emerged by the end of day 1:

1)    Incentives governing the academic community undermine the potential success of the research-policy nexus in creating and delivering innovative policy solutions,

2)    Established relationships and trust are vital components of successful collaborative efforts.  These relationships are difficult to build and sustain,
